urn:contentItem:5VCM-4T41-F103-32FY-00000-00City considers changes to its burn bylaw2019-02-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:11ZLexisNexisNEWSCity considers changes to its burn bylaw

A Terrace resident is asking the city to review its residential burn ban, calling the current year-wide restrictions too harsh to properly manage excess debris on forested properties.

Vince Heslenfeld says he has been burning on his property on the bench for the past 38 years, once or twice a year, to help decrease the chances of a forest fire.

"Up until two months ago, the [Terrace Fire Department] never received a complaint," Heslenfeld says, noting that his neighbour's property recently had all their trees cleared, making it easier for fires on his property to be seen.

"All owners of forested property should be encouraged to keep them clear of combustible debris," he adds. "Our residential property burning ban accomplishes the exact opposite."

Currently, burning is allowed in agricultural, commercial, industrial or rural zones areas with a permit, but not in residential areas, according to the Terrace Fire Prevention Bylaw. A permit may also be removed if the smoke proves to be a nuisance to neighbours.

It was originally introduced after a resident voiced concerns regarding the air quality in their area caused by the fire smoke. Heslenfeld says while it would have been reasonable to impose some restrictions then, a total residential ban was a step too far.

READ MORE: B.C. communities call for wildfire prevention help

"Imposing a fire ban causes many other problems, the unwanted wood just not just go away and it can't be ignored either," he says. "Homeowners now have to come up with other ways of dealing with the material they previously burned."

Terrace's fire chief and bylaw officer have given Heslenfeld two options to get rid of the excess material - either through curbside collection or to take the trimmings to the transfer station in Thornhill, which costs $70 to drop off.

In order for the material to be approved for curbside, Henslenfeld says he spent almost two days cutting up branches from one fruit tree and stuffing them into large paper bags for collection.

"I sustained repetitive strain injury to my hand," he says. "By the way, this was just for one fruit tree - I have six."

Heslenfeld requested that two burn days be introduced per year, one in the spring and one in the fall, published well in advance so those troubled by smoke can prepare.

"Without that, I would likely do as my neighbour did and get rid of all of the trees on my property," he says.

READ MORE: Smoke keeps air quality risks for some B.C. regions, rain moves through others

Coun. Lynne Christiansen says implementation of a residential fire ban was a bit of a stretch, and may not hurt to have a look at the existing bylaw to make it more workable for people who have larger properties or acreages.

"It's a bit of a hardship to expect [residents] to clear, gather, take [wood] to the dump and pay the amount for it," says Christiansen. "Perhaps, in the middle of January when it's wet enough and there's no danger, that there should be some provision so they can have some time to do that burning on their own property."

She added that burning excess branches or dry wood can be fire-preventative, and recalled a time in the 1900s when a forest fire engulfed the Bench area.

"We sure don't want that now with the houses up there," Christiansen says, acknowledging that any changes to the bylaw would come with recommendations from the city's fire department and bylaw officer.

HALIFAX-Nova Scotia firefighters are heading to Alberta on Thursday to help fight wildfires burning in Alberta.

On Monday, nearly 5,000 people were ordered to evacuate from the northern Alberta town of High Level as an out-of-control wildfire fuelled by strong winds loomed just five kilometres away. Meanwhile, residents of Marlboro, Alta., a town west of Edmonton, were allowed home Monday after being evacuated the night before due to another wildfire.

In a news release on Wednesday, Nova Scotia's Department of Lands and Forestry said a 21-person crew of Alberta-bound wildfire fighters are expected to remain on the fire line for about two weeks, although their exact location has yet to be determined.

The department said Nova Scotia's assistance was requested through the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, adding that current fire conditions in Nova Scotia made it possible for the province to meet the request.

The news release said the department will ensure proper firefighting resources are maintained within Nova Scotia. The province is a member of the Canadian Mutual Aid Resource Sharing Agreement, which ensures all provinces and territories will receive help if forest fires become "too big to handle."

The affected province covers the costs of crews from the jurisdictions that send help.

Yvette d'Entremont is a Halifax-based reporter focusing on health. Follow her on Twitter: @ydentremont

B.C. Finance Minister Carole James released the province's second quarter financial update Tuesday, downgrading the forecast surplus for the current year and using the bulk of the government's forecast allowance to keep the books out of the red.

The projection at the halfway point of the 2017-18 fiscal year is a surplus of $190 million, down $56 million from the first-quarter projection. The biggest jump in provincial spending was $152 million to cover costs of the summer forest fire season. Forest fire efforts also accounted for most of a jump of 267 full-time equivalent B.C. government jobs in the summer.

On the revenue side, the biggest change was a reduction of $643 million in anticipated income tax revenues. James said that was based on the federal government's update of personal and corporate income taxes collected during 2016, down from the previous forecast.

Another revenue drop of $109 million from earlier forecasts came in commercial Crown corporation revenue. That is mostly due to a downgrade of revenues from ICBC, which continues to struggle with increased claims and legal costs.

RELATED: Report warns of more ICBC rate increases

Other revenues continued at a healthy pace in the quarter from July to September, including property transfer tax, which has been the province's cash cow during the hot real estate market in recent years. Expected revenues from that tax for the current year were increased by $175 million.

Retail sales also continued to rise in the second quarter, resulting in an upward adjustment of $51 million.

Another bright spot was forest revenues, with the provincial revenue forecast up $55 million, due mostly to higher timber tenure stumpage rates. B.C. lumber prices are near record highs, with high demand from the U.S. despite 20 per cent countervail and anti-dumping duties imposed by the U.S. government at the Canadian border.

B.C. Liberal finance critic Shirley Bond said the strong economic growth is a result of the previous government's policies.

"Although the NDP inherited a $2.7 billion surplus, they have already managed to dip into British Columbia's savings and they haven't even fulfilled most of their major campaign spending promises, including $10-a-day daycare and a $400 renter subsidy," Bond said.

James said the NDP's child care and housing pledges are over 10 years, and can be achieved as long as B.C. continues to have strong economic growth.

The tourists have never been tracked down.</p><p>The two-day fire destroyed 17,000 hectares of lumber worth more than a billion dollars, said Forests Ministry spokesman Bruce Hutchinson.</p><p>A total of 400 people tried to control the raging fire with 14 helicopters, 60 bulldozers and an assortment of other vehicles.</p><p>"The 300-foot flames jumped over mountains, roads and rivers . . nothing get compensation from the government, the families went to the ombudsman in 1990.</p><p>Forests ministry spokesman Jim Dunlop said insurance adjustors will visit the families next week to assess the THUNDER BAY, Ont. _ The Ministry of Natural Resources is reminding outdoor enthusiasts to be careful with fire this weekend.

Fire information officer Deb MacLean says fire activity is starting to heat up in northwestern Ontario with 15 new fires reported over two days this week.

MacLean says Dryden District has two active fires burning in the Ignace area, with no problems anticipated.

Kenora District has one active fire listed as under control, about 35 kilometres northwest of the city.

Nipigon District is dealing with three lightning-caused fires burning in the remote north.

Red Lake District has three active fires. Two, about 30 and 110 km east and southeast of Red Lake, were caused by lightning and both are listed as not under control at 50 and 340 hectares, respectively.

MacLean said Sioux Lookout District is dealing with two fires which are classified as not under control.

A 10-hectare fire is burning 65 km east of Ear Falls, while a four-hectare fire is burning near Mishkeegogamang First Nation.

Thunder Bay District has two active fires. One blaze at Gull Bay is classed as being held, and another, burning about 20 km south of Armstrong in storm damaged forest, is classed as not under control, MacLean added.

(Thunder Bay Chronicle-Journal)

(CP) _ Fire crews worked into the night Sunday battling a wildfire that threatened to destroy dozens of homes in and near the small southwestern Alberta mining community of Hillcrest.</p><p nitf:lede="true">About 100 people from east Hillcrest and from some rural homes south of town were ordered to leave by mid-afternoon as the fire roared through mountainous terrain to within five kilometres of town. In addition, all of the town's 700 citizens were alerted by the Municipal District of Crowsnest Pass to pack up and be prepared to leave their homes on an hour's notice.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Burning mainly eastward, the blaze appeared to have bypassed the town by late evening, but then forced rural residents further east in the Municipal District of Pincher Creek to flee their homes. Pincher Creek officials declared a state of emergency in the Tapay Road area, south of Highway 3, from Lees Lake south to the hamlet of Beaver Mines.</p><p>"There's no relief. The fire continues to burn out of control,'' said Rick Strickland, provincial fire information officer. "Right now, we're concentrating our efforts on saving the community.''</p><p>The blaze, known as the Lost Creek fire, has so far consumed more than 70 square kilometres of tinder-dry forest. As it continued burning out of control, the number of workers battling the blaze swelled to 400 Sunday with more on the way from around Alberta. Five air tanker groups and at least 12 helicopters fought the battle from the air. Ground crews worked feverishly through the day setting up hoses and sprinkler systems on rural homes and at a 74-unit mobile home park on the southern edge of Hillcrest.</p><p>Bill and Janise Dickerson loaded what they could from their mobile home into the back of their small station wagon and then waited to hear if they would have to leave.</p><p>"We're just kind of waiting and hoping and praying,'' said Janise. "We just took the photos and the things you can't replace.''</p><p>Their unit is one of several in the Monte Vista Mobile Home Park situated just a few metres from dense bush.</p><p>Two towering, 63,000-litre water tanks were set up nearby to feed numerous hoses snaking their way through the park to large sprinklers positioned on its perimeter.</p><p>Late Saturday night, the fire skipped across to the east side of Adanac Road, less than 10 kilometres south of Hillcrest.</p><p>Rural residents along Adanac Road spent the weekend hauling out whatever furniture and belongings they could manage in the short time they had.</p><p>Jerry and Sheila Kumiszczo loaded furniture, including dressers and a piano, onto a flatbed trailer before leaving their 232-square-metre (2,500-square-foot) home nestled on a 1.6-hectare (four-acre) lot.</p><p>"We put a lot of blood, sweat and tears into this place,'' said Jerry. "If I could pack the house on my back, it would be with me, too.''</p><p>Stuart Dalziel and his wife Louise were also anxious.</p><p>"It's pretty devastating,'' Dalziel said. "This is our retirement place, and you just hope (the fire threat) is not going to be. There's nothing you can do. You just drive away from it.''</p><p>The fire, which began Wednesday, is the largest of six wildfires currently being fought in Alberta.</p><p>Homes were also being threatened by fire in southwestern British Columbia on Sunday.</p><p>One resident was forced to leave his home in Chilko Lake, B.C., and 17 others were put on alert after a forest fire near the town continued to grow on Sunday.</p><p>About 120 firefighters were trying to isolate the 35-square-kilometre blaze. It was about 20 per cent contained Sunday, said fire information officer Kilah Whitehead.</p><p>British Columbia also sent a 20-person crew on Sunday to help battle the Farewell Creek fire in Washington State.</p><p>On Sunday that fire had engulfed 27 square kilometres and was eight kilometres from the southern B.C. town of Keremeos.</p><p>Also south of the border, a 76-square-kilometre fire was burning in the northwest corner of Montana's Glacier National Park, just six miles south of the Canadian border.</p><p>That fire has destroyed five homes, damaged one and burned 19 outbuildings. About 100 homes and cabins were still threatened Sunday.</p><p>"Winds have been picking up and they've been doing some burnouts around some houses,'' Jim Pudelka of the Flathead National Forest said Sunday afternoon.</p><p>"The Canadian government is a little worried about us burning clear up to them. They've already got a contingency plan in place to allow residents (in far northwestern Montana) to escape into Canada,'' Pudelka said.</p><p>Further east, Manitoba firefighters continued to battle a 37-square kilometre fire that has been burning north of Thompson for more than two weeks.</p><p>Tom Mirus, field supervisor for Manitoba's fire program, said crews did a terrific job defending against the massive forest fire throughout the weekend, but weather over the next 24 hours could toughen the task considerably.</p><p>A hot, muggy day, which may include thunderstorms, was predicted for Monday.</p><p>(Lethbridge Herald, Winnipeg Free Press)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier "This points to a potentially early and agressive fire season.''</p><p>The move comes only months after a government-commissioned report slammed the department saying under-staffed and under-equipped crews weren't prepared for a record number of forest fires in 1998 that cost Alberta taxpayers more than $200 million to fight.</p><p>The KPMG management consultants report released last December said years of budget cuts left the province without enough firefighters and aircraft. As a result Alberta had to bring in crews from other provinces at twice the cost. The total number of certified firefighters had dropped by one-third since 1993, the report said. Fewer than half the lookout towers were manned in May 1998 despite warnings of an early fire season.</p><p>Ty Lund was the minister at the time. The KPMG study was the second report to blame staff cuts for higher firefighting costs. Auditor general Peter Valentine had similar findings in his annual report released last October.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata One of the biggest - Thunder Bay Fire 21 - is burning<br/> out of control near Lake Nipigon.<br/> We haven't seen a decent rain since last year,'' said Mitch<br/> Miller, a fire information officer at the Ontario natural<br/> resources ministry's Fire Management Centre in Dryden.<br/> We don't have any rain in the forecast, so things are going to<br/> get worse before they get any better.''</p><p>Miller said the unusually dry conditions mean the fires are<br/> burning both above and below ground, making the 10 that are still<br/> burning devilishly difficult to control and extinguish.<br/> It's so dry the fire is actually burning into the ground, and<br/> that means our fire rangers are having to spend more time on the<br/> fire to make sure that they dig out all the hot spots before<br/> they're declared out,'' he said.<br/> Under these conditions we've seen explosive fire growth.''<br/> The global phenomenon known as El Nino - a massive warming of<br/> Pacific Ocean water that has wreaked weather havoc around the<br/> globe - is just one of the causes for the drought-like<br/> conditions, said Environment Canada forecaster Jack Dennahower.<br/> By this time of year it should be pouring rain up there in<br/> Northern Ontario,'' he said. But this seems to be that<br/> particular year when they're not getting anything.''<br/> Thunder Bay, the bull's-eye of the bone-dry northwestern forests,<br/> was placed under an open burning ban by the ministry Friday.<br/> The ban extends from Lake Nipigon's western shores to the<br/>Manitoba border, and from the U.S.-Canada boundary north 400<br/> kilometres to the Pickle Lake region.<br/> Things are going to get worse before they get any better.'<br/><br/> Environment Canada climatologist Sandi Radecki said the Thunder<br/> Bay region has had an unusually dry April, with only 4.2<br/> millimetres of precipitation.<br/> Normally they should be getting 47 millimetres of precipitation<br/> in April - they've had less than a 10th of that.''<br/> Although southern Ontario had a wetter-than-normal March - offset<br/> only slightly by somewhat drier conditions than usual in April -<br/> the fire danger remains a cause for concern to officials.<br/> Several weeks without significant rainfall in the Parry Sound<br/> area led two fire departments - Parry Sound and Seguin Township<br/> just to the south - to impose bans on open burning until further<br/> notice.<br/> I won't lift the fire ban here until we get at least 24 hours<br/> of steady rain,'' said Parry Sound Fire Chief Garnet Schenk.<br/> In Seguin Township, which takes in a vast area stretching from<br/> Parry Sound south to Mactier, and from Georgian Bay to the<br/> Muskoka Lakes in the east, Fire Chief Abe Kamerman had lifted the<br/> ban for several weeks.<br/> But, at this point I can't take the risk with it so dry,''<br/> Kamerman said.<br/> A worry, he added, are the thousands of seasonal residents who<br/> are headed up to clean out their cottages and tidy up their<br/> yards.<br/> Many seasonal residents are coming into the area to clean their<br/> cottages now,'' Kamerman said.<br/> I wanted to make sure the fire ban was in place before the<br/> weekend.''<br/> With files from Mark Ladan<br/><br/><br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7W35-J9H1-2R6R-503G-00000-00Insurance expert warns against renewed B.C. forest-fire risk2009-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:11ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSInsurance expert warns against renewed B.C. forest-fire riskCP

KAMLOOPS, B.C. _ An insurance expert is warning that more B.C. homeowners are risking losses due to forest fires because they're under-insured.

Karen Hopkins-Lee, chief underwriter for Canadian Direct Insurance, says people living in fire-threatened areas should make sure their policies are updated to reflect the current value of their homes.

Hopkins-Lee also says homeowners should be making sure their properties are free of vegetation and debris that can fuel a fire.

Wildfires ravaged parts of the B.C. Interior in 2003, forcing more than 50,000 people to evacuate and destroying more than 200 homes near Kamloops and Kelowna.

Hopkins-Lee says damage claims for the 2003 blazes came to almost $200 million.

An early start to this year's B.C. fire season has prompted concerns the province is facing another year like 2003, when many residents who lost their homes had little or no coverage.

''What came out of the Okanagan and the McClure fire was simply under-insurance,'' said Hopkins-Lee.

''People are doing renovations to their homes, whether it's additions or upgrading within their home. But the insurance values were not reflecting those changes.''

Besides updating insurance policies, she recommends other precautions in fire-prone areas, including investing in fire-resistant roofing, cutting back shrubbery and removing dried grass and leaves.

Several fires last month forced small-scale evacuations and one in the Cariboo region destroyed a couple of homes.

The largest current fire is a 23,000-hectare blaze near the B.C.-Yukon border that began with a lightning strike June 1.

More than a dozen people were forced from their homes but the evacuation order has since been rescinded.

The B.C. Fire Protection Branch says the blaze is about 35 per cent contained and a crew of about 20 firefighters, helped by recent rains, are managing the fire.

(CP) - Once it was Ron Giselbrecht's home, tucked among the other neat houses in this hideaway community in the Alberta bush country.</p><p nitf:lede="true">By Tuesday, it was a charred and blackened hole, surrounded by twisted metal and ill-smelling burned plastic. The only thing the forest fire left untouched, as if in mockery, was the cheerful orange nameplate at the front of the driveway.</p><p>-BODY- "What can you say when you look a pile of rubbish?'' Giselbrecht asked in sorrow and anger. "I don't have a home any more.''</p><p>Giselbrecht and his neighbours returned home to take stock of what a raging forest fire left of their possessions, the day after they were evacuated in the face of a blaze that has been described as charging through the woods like a locomotive.</p><p>Nine homes were destroyed, some as if by a bomb.</p><p>"You're just in awe when you see stuff like this,'' said Eugene Nadeau, kicking at the remains of his son's toys in what used to be his shed.</p><p>Shelly Knahs watched her husband poke through the rubble of her parent's home, in which she grew up. He held up a pair of ceramic figurines, their colours bleached by the heat of fire.</p><p>"Isn't that sad,'' she said. "There are the little statues that stood on their coffee table.''</p><p>"Do you want them?'' her husband asked.</p><p>"No. They're junk now,'' Knahs responded.</p><p>Dale Wade drove out from nearby Westlock to survey the ruins of his cabin.</p><p>"There's nothing there at all,'' he said. "It's flattened. Melted. My Ski-Doos are just melted down to little piles of nuthin's.''</p><p>But the fire was oddly selective.</p><p>A child's swing set stood undamaged beside a house in ruins, its cheerful blue and white paint not even scorched. A line of laundry hung unmarked by a single ember, while a few yards away the fire burned hot enough to melt the zinc coating off the wheel wells of an off-road vehicle.</p><p>"I couldn't believe it,'' said Giselbrecht.</p><p>"My house was gone. The ones that I figured would be gone, some of them are still standing.''</p><p>Chisholm was a nice little community with a couple dozen permanent residents and a growing population of cottagers, said Giselbrecht.</p><p>On weekends, the place would be full of people enjoying the woods and the nearby Athabasca River, driving quads and snow machines. Now, he doesn't know what's going to happen.</p><p>"It's too soon. It's too soon.''</p><p>Al Pearson lost a brand-new log home, as well as the trailer he'd renovated for his mother. He doesn't know what the future will bring, either.</p><p>"I'll go back to the city, I guess. What can you do? You can't even salvage anything.''</p><p>But some residents felt none of the loss was necessary. Several harangued a forestry official while an RCMP officer stood by to keep the peace.</p><p>"If they'd have went to work the night this fire started there wouldn't have been a fire,'' said Giselbrecht.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5T8C-CSX1-F103-34Y7-00000-00West Kelowna looks for confirmation that West Kelowna Transmission Project is provincial priority2018-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:11ZLexisNexisNEWSWest Kelowna looks for confirmation that West Kelowna Transmission Project is provincial priority

At today's meetings with provincial representatives at the 2018 Union of B.C. Municipalities convention in Whistler, mayor and council continued to lobby for a review of provincial policing levels serving out of the West Kelowna RCMP Detachment and sought confirmation that the West Kelowna Transmission Project continues to be a provincial priority.

Mayor Doug Findlater and members of West Kelowna council were provided with short face-to-face meetings with ministry representatives and discussed the following issues with:

Mike Farnworth, Minister of Public Safety and Solicitor General to discuss rural detachment policing levels. West Kelowna is concerned that the province's contribution towards rural policing is not adequate and is asking for a review of services by the province. West Kelowna pays for the municipal police force, 26 officers, to serve the City of West Kelowna. The province pays for 24 officers to serve Westbank First Nation, Peachland, Central Okanagan West Electoral Area, Highway 97C/Okanagan Connector to Sunset Main, Okanagan Lake from Peachland to Lake Okanagan Resort and rural areas on the east side of Okanagan Lake including Big White and Joe Rich. With RCMP requesting eight additional officers from West Kelowna, which would amount to a 4.5 per cent tax increase, West Kelowna wants to ensure it is not taking on policing costs outside of its jurisdiction.

"A condition of our Municipal Policing Agreement with the province to conduct reviews of service levels has not been met. Council is hesitant to entertain hiring more officers, particularly since it will mean a large tax increase for taxpayers, without a solid understanding of provincial policing out of the West Kelowna detachment," said Findlater. "We don't want West Kelowna taxpayers paying for policing other areas and we need to be sure that isn't happening."

West Kelowna is in a unique situation with two large, concentrated urban populations under the jurisdiction of the rural police force. Findlater said Minister Farnworth indicated E-Division has new staff who could do the analysis that is necessary.

Ministry of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources to discuss the City's ongoing interest in ensuring BC Hydro construct a second transmission line into the community. Currently, there is only one power source which distributes power to West Kelowna, Westbank First Nation, Peachland, parts of the Regional District of Central Okanagan and as far south as Summerland. A commitment was made by B.C. Hydro to construct the second power source, however a final route has not been determined.

"We are reminding BC Hydro about the promise to provide power security to our communities, and emphasizing that the new route should be considered with potential forest fire threat in mind," said Findlater. "The Smith Creek forest fire in 2014, which came very close to the power line, reminds us how vulnerable we are if the power supply is compromised."

Findlater indicated that ministry staff said the project is advancing and it is expected B.C. Hydro will have shovels in the ground by 2023 with a projected completion date in 2025.

They returned on Saturday.</p><p>No Guelph tax money was used.</p><p>Kovach said the residents of Kelowna were appreciative of Guelph's help, which is part of ongoing Communities in Bloom initiatives.</p><p>"I even had someone offer to help me with my laundry in a laundromat," she said.</p><p>To honour Guelph's contribution, Kelowna planted a sugar maple and dedicated a park bench.</p><p>"I want to compliment the parties that went," Mayor Kate Quarrie said at the council meeting.</p><p>She also commended acting city administrator Gus Stahlmann for his initiative in getting the Kelowna ReLeaf project off the ground, and for "your continuing commitment to the environment."</p><p>Stahlmann was part of the team which travelled to Kelowna. The volunteer group also included a nine-member contingent from McNeil Consumer Healthcare and two others from a division of its parent company Johnson & Johnson.</p><p>Kelowna lost nearly 26,000 hectares of forest in the fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - About 600 people fled their homes Sunday as strong winds pushed a forest fire to within kilometres of their communities.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Residents of Seymourville, Hollow Water First Nation and Manigotagan - three small communities clustered on the east shore of Lake Winnipeg - were told to leave their homes late Saturday evening, said Bob Buck of Manitoba Natural Resources.</p><p>-BODY- Unseasonably warm temperatures up to 26 C and winds gusting up to 70 kilometres per hour pushed the blaze to within four kilometres of the communities, about 150 kilometres northeast of Winnipeg.</p><p>Residents went to Bissett, a town about 40 kilometres east of the evacuated area.</p><p>"Everything happened so fast that everyone's minds are mixed up,'' said a woman from Manigotagan who would only give her name as Brenda.</p><p>"My ten-year-old was crying - we were totally in shock. It's not easy to leave your home.''</p><p>Fourteen people ended up crowding into Brenda's hotel room to spend the night.</p><p>"Everybody's settling in,'' Marlene Wynne said Sunday as she worked the cash register at Wynne's Place, a general store in Bissett.</p><p>"We got more people coming here than actually live here,'' she said.</p><p>Residents were put up at the community hall, school and the town's hotel, said Diana Soroka of Manitoba Emergency Management Organization.</p><p>Another 100 went to Lac du Bonnet, where they will stay at the local Legion hall, she added.</p><p>About 100 left Bissett to stay with family in Winnipeg and other places, Soroka said.</p><p>Buck said the fire - which started Saturday - had grown to 26 kilometres long and two kilometres wide by Sunday. The fire likely was caused by man, he added.</p><p>About 500 firefighters, 30 helicopters and five water bombers were battling the blaze.</p><p>A forest fire also destroyed four homes Saturday in St. Theresa Point, a remote, fly-in community about 400 kilometres northeast of Winnipeg.</p><p>Buck said the fire hazard is extreme in most of Manitoba's forested areas. Temperatures and winds are forecast to drop over the next few days, which will help the crews out fighting the fire, Buck said.</p><p>"But it doesn't look like much rain is coming with it,'' Buck added.</p><p>There were 64 fires burning in Manitoba on Sunday. Twenty new fires started Saturday, all man-made. There is a ban on open fires across the province. (Winnipeg Free Press)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:50TB-TPR1-DYTJ-11DM-00000-00Sizzling heat blamed for spurring latest round of B.C. forest fire evacuations2010-08-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:11ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSSizzling heat blamed for spurring latest round of B.C. forest fire evacuationsCP

KAMLOOPS, B.C. _ Sizzling temperatures are expected to cool in B.C. over the next several days, but that's little immediate consolation for the province's exhausted firefighters.

''We are battling Mother Nature right now,'' said fire information officer Alyson Couch.

''But she has the upper hand.''

Hot, dry conditions are forecast to continue through Tuesday and Couch said forestry crews anticipated more aggressive behaviour on B.C.'s 277 wildfires.

''The good news is that some of the fires are starting to see some containment, so we aren't losing everywhere,'' she said, while noting conditions in the Cariboo and Northwest Fire Centres are still bad.

Sixteen stubborn fires were among the many being handled by those two fire centres, including several huge blazes west and north of Williams Lake that have scorched hundreds of square kilometres of bush and continue to keep residents out of their homes.

Thirteen new blazes were sparked in B.C. on Monday.

Evacuations were ordered for residents near the 130-square kilometre wildfire near Tweedsmuir Provincial Park in west-central B.C.

A nearly six-square kilometre blaze on the Central Coast, 45 kilometres north of Bella Coola, forced evacuations and alerts Monday evening, covering several fishing lodges and other properties along the Dean River, a renowned steelhead fishing destination.

A 20-square kilometre fire also prompted additional evacuation alerts southeast of Burns Lake, about three hours west of Prince George.

B.C. has spent $117 million battling 1,448 wildfires that have charred a total of 1,660 square kilometres of woodland since April.

About another 1,000 people, including residents of the nearby community of Hillcrest, were on one-hour evacuation notice.</p><p>Both Hillcrest and Blairmore residents were forced to evacuate last week because of the blaze and had only been home for a couple of days.</p><p>Citizens reported spot fires growing on the mountain's west side and wind-whipped flareups near Hillcrest, which sits among the trees on Turtle Mountain, were making that community vulnerable again.</p><p>Fire officials said the blaze, that has ravenously eaten through timber for about three weeks, grew substantially Monday.</p><p>Dry, hot weather has challenged crews trying to fight the out-of-control fire as it rages in the mountain pass on the Alberta-British Columbia boundary.</p><p>Thunderstorms were forecast for last night -- a mixed blessing for crews who want the rain, but worry about possible lightning strikes igniting more fires.</p><p>Battling the wildfire has cost Hillcrest more than $800,000. urn:contentItem:52WB-1WG1-JC8F-M2W4-00000-00Canadian Natural Resources Limited Provides an Update on Fort McMurray Region Forest Fires2011-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:11ZLexisNexisCanadian Natural Resources Limited Provides an Update on Fort McMurray Region Forest Fires

CALGARY, ALBERTA--(Marketwire - May 16, 2011) - A number of forest fires continue to burn in the oil sands region near Fort McMurray with Canadian Natural Resources Limited ("Canadian Natural" or the "Company") (TSX:CNQ) (NYSE:CNQ) responding to a forest fire near its Horizon Oil Sands site. The forest fire remains approximately 150 metres from its Chelsea Lodge, one of three staff camps on site. A fire barrier has been put in place and to date has been successful in diverting the forest fire away from the lodge and the balance of the Horizon Oil Sands site. The forest fire has had no impact on any facilities on the Horizon Oil Sands site and steps have been taken to minimize the potential impact of the forest fires on the Horizon facilities and its operations.

Approximately 1,300 camp residents and personnel have been evacuated from both the Chelsea lodge and the Calumet Lodge and no injuries have been reported. Labour relations staff is making arrangements to get non-essential Canadian Natural personnel and contract staff off site.

Canadian Natural's number one priority is the safety and security of its workers. All in-bound flights and First Canada bussing from Fort McMurray to Horizon site have been cancelled for Monday, May 16, 2011. All non-essential, non-operational personnel will be notified when they can expect to return to work once the forest fire situation has passed.

Canadian Natural is a senior oil and natural gas production company, with continuing operations in its core areas located in Western Canada, the U.K. portion of the North Sea and Offshore West Africa.

(CP) _ Twelve families returned to their homes Monday after a forest fire forced them to evacuate the day before.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But the fire, which has charred 19 square kilometres near the Alberta-Montana boundary on the eastern edge of Waterton Lakes National Park, was still considered out of control and 200 firefighters were trying to get a handle on it.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Improving weather eased concerns the fire might scar the park, said spokeswoman Janice Smith.</p><p>"We're concerned about damage it may cause to the park but it's not a big a concern anymore,'' she said.</p><p>"It came within a matter of feet from the boundary but didn't go any further because one of our typical Pacific Coast systems moved in and hunkered down in the valley and it started pouring rain.''</p><p>Brian Phillips, administrator of Cardston County, said the burning fire sent billowing clouds of black smoke into the air on Sunday.</p><p>Rancher Wayne Jensen, whose log cabin is one of the closest to the blaze, said he and other evacuated residents spent Sunday night in their trucks a few kilometres away so they could be near their ranches in case the fire threatened their livestock.</p><p>"There's not a lot of fuel left for the fire in this direction but if the wind keeps up it could blow it right over here,'' said Jensen, whose house was coated in fire-retardant foam and surrounded by sprinklers.</p><p>Jensen said the fire will clear out years of accumulated dead wood.</p><p>"It's been a fire waiting to happen in there,'' he said.</p><p>"It should make the grazing even better, if anything, when the grass grows back where the trees were.''</p><p>Phillips said the 12 families returned home to hazy conditions on Monday. Some of residents remain on one-hour evacuation alert.</p><p>The fire is believed to have started in a community pasture, Phillips said.</p><p>It was detected Sunday morning and firefighters were able to jump on it quickly because they were on standby due to warm, dry conditions that have caused a high fire hazard in the area.</p><p>Shannon Oakley, spokeswoman for Alberta Sustainable Resource Development, said it's not unusual for fires to break out in October.</p><p>There were 20 firefighters battling the blaze on Monday and another 175 en route.</p><p>The blaze comes at the end of a highly destructive fire season in Alberta and British Columbia. The largest fire in Alberta was in the Crowsnest Pass where crews battled for weeks to get the blaze under control.</p><p>The Crowsnest Pass fire started July 23 and roared through more than 210 square kilometres of forest. It burned out of control for 31 days and 1,000 residents of Blairmore were evacuated twice when the blaze threatened their homes.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5P0N-V2F1-F105-60XK-00000-00Local firefighters on standby to mobilize north2017-07-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:11ZLexisNexisNEWSLocal firefighters on standby to mobilize northPhil Melnychuk

Local police are helping out with the forest fire catastrophe in the Interior and firefighters soon could be joining them.

Ridge Meadows RCMP sent three officers to help traffic control and security on Sunday, possibly in the Ashcroft area. E Division RCMP headquarters put out the request as it tries to maintain public safety in the areas where roads are closed and people have been ordered from their homes.

Numerous roads are closed in the central region, and Cache Creek and 100 Mile House have been evacuated as fires sweep through the tinder-dry forests.

Pitt Meadows Fire and Rescue is also currently discussing sending firefighters up north. But no decisions have been made yet. "We don't want to do anything deplete Pitt Meadows," assistant fire chief Mike Larson said Monday. They could send the back-up truck to the Interior if requested.

They department has sent in a list to the ministry indicating what it could spare. That comprises four, paid-on-call firefighters along with the department's back up pumper truck that carries water with ladders and hoses.

"Basically, we're on stand by. We're ready to go if the province needs us."

Maple Ridge Fire and Rescue chief Howard Exner said he hasn't received a request from the province for any assistance. "We are looking at it right now to see what we can do."

He wants to make sure whatever Maple Ridge sends won't be needed if a catastrophe happens locally. "We have our own responsibilities here we have to take care of as well."

Because of the dry conditions, approaching extreme forest fire danger rating in the Lower Mainland, the City of Maple Ridge imposed a burning ban on Friday, prohibiting all open fires, in the rural areas. Fireworks or pyrotechnics are also banned, although barbecues and hibachis are allowed. Exner said Monday that ban could be strengthened later if conditions worsen.

Anyone who lights a campfire could be fined between $500 and $1,000.

Fires of any kind are banned year round in Pitt Meadows.

Road closures can be found at www.drivebc.ca

Wildfires can be found at www.bcwildfire.ca or on Twitter @BCGovFireInfo and Facebook @BCForestFireInfo.

urn:contentItem:5WND-BVG1-JDH1-C372-00000-00BC Ferries encouraging travellers to practice fire safety this summer2019-07-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:11ZLexisNexisNEWSBC Ferries encouraging travellers to practice fire safety this summer

BC Ferries has a special message for travellers this summer.

It's encouraging passengers aboard vessels in the northern and southern Gulf Islands and northern Vancouver Island areas to practice wildfire safety.

"Good morning/afternoon passengers. It's very dry out there and the southern/northern Gulf Islands are at risk to wildfire," the public service announcement says. "Please check with the local fire department for wildfire prevention restrictions and use extreme caution with cigarette butts, barbecues and all other heat producing items. BC Ferries proudly provides these messages to help protect B.C. and its beautiful Gulf Islands from wildfires."

While the B.C. wildfire season has been far less active than experts initially predicted, the fire hazard on Vancouver Island is moderate to high.

"We're making these announcements to help spread the word on fire safety, both on board our vessels and in the communities we serve, because it's so important at this time of year," says Corrine Storey, BC Ferries vice president and chief operating officer. "Wildfires devastate our province during the summer and we want to do our part to contribute to overall fire safety in these coastal communities."

BC Ferries is also hosting Pender Island Fire Rescue at the Swartz Bay terminal for the 12th year this summer. The fire department brings an antique fire truck to the terminal on Friday afternoons during the summer and firefighters provide information to Southern Gulf Island travellers about fire safety and fire bans.

urn:contentItem:4P5S-7HY0-TX4V-K34K-00000-00Hot dry weather boosts forest fire risk in southeast B.C.2007-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:59:11ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSHot dry weather boosts forest fire risk in southeast B.C.CP

TRAIL, B.C. (CP) _ Hot, dry weather since the start of the month has resulted in a skyrocketing fire risk in southeastern British Columbia but no significant fires so far.

The fire risk has increased from very low to moderate in the Southeast Fire Region a week and a half ago to high to extreme as of Tuesday.

''The reason we haven't been busy is we haven't been getting any lightning and there haven't been any started by human activity,'' said Corwin Odlund, information officer at the Southeast Fire Centre in Castlegar.

''We are expecting lightning later this week, but right now we are just sitting and waiting.''

The centre is keeping an eye on 11 small fires of less than 10 hectares that have been contained, including one at the landfill site in Trail.

Fire warnings are based on the state of fuels. A high risk means that small fuel items such as grass and needles are dry as well as dead trees and branches. An extreme fire risk means that standing trees are also drying out.

''In most areas, the standing fuel isn't too bad right now,'' Odlund said.

The Southeast Fire Centre covers the area extending from the U.S. border to Mica Dam in the north and from the Okanagan Highlands in the west to the B.C.-Alberta border in the east.

We were about 200 feet up and we plowed into the trees.''</p><p>As the aircraft dropped out of the sky, Thorburn radioed for help. After scrambling out of the helicopter the three men hurried away from the fire through the brush to a lake where they were picked up by another helicopter and taken to hospital in nearby Whitecourt.</p><p>"Our helicopter is probably cinders by now,'' said Raham after being given a clean bill of health.</p><p>Thorburn also escaped without a scratch but the pilot suffered a cut to the head and was kept overnight in hospital for observation.</p><p>An investigation by Transport Canada into the crash will have to be carried out against the dramatic background of the largest and most menacing forest fire in the province.</p><p>The Bell 206 was owned by Vancouver-based Highland Helicopters.
